Summary I am currently working as an Associate at BBC Research & Consulting. My primary role at BBC is as a project manager in our market research and diversity study practice areas. In addition to project management, my areas of responsibility at BBC include market research, segmentation analysis, membership research, GIS analysis and cartography, survey design, data management, data analysis, proposal writing, and technical writing. You could say that I am a jack of all trades here. 
 
My primary intellectual interests are energy policy, sustainable and healthy food systems, market research, and sustainability. In addition to my experience at BBC, I also have previous work experience in the energy policy, sustainability, GIS, and online advertising fields.

 Experience Assistant Dean Stanford University September 2014  – Present (1 year) I facilitate financial, operational and programmatic functions of Residential Education. Assistant Director Stanford University September 2013  –  August 2014  (1 year) Residential Education I am responsible for the dining experience of the third of Stanford students living in the 34 student managed residential communities collectively known as "the Row". Student "kitchen managers" are selected by their peers to cooperatively procure and prepare meals in these houses, either in partnership with their fellow residents (in the seven co-ops) or with a professional chef (in the 27 self-ops). The dining experience in these houses is designed to be a synergistic learning experience that creates a meaningful sense of community among the members of the house.  
 
As the first person to serve in this role, I am currently focused on redefining the values and goals of our dining experience, and the educational outcomes of the student kitchen manager program; in academic year 2014 I will be implementing and communicating the results of this re-defining and -imagining process. 
 
My responsibilities include: 
Train, supervise and support the 43 students selected for these roles. 
Facilitate maintenance and ensure county code compliance for the 34 commercial kitchens. 
Lead inquiry process to inform the articulation of values, goals and educational outcomes. 
Advocate for and represent the student managed dining program and its shifting nature within the University. 
 
Additionally I am:  
A member of our departmental Assessment Metrics team, working to gather and make sense of quantitative and qualitative data in order to help our department make well-informed decisions. 
A member of our inaugural Communications team, in which we are developing a departmental "collaborative creative process", creating brand identity and materials production quality expectations, and strategizing about inter- and intra-departmental communications methods. Program Associate Stanford University September 2011  –  August 2013  (2 years) Residential Education Fifty percent of my focus was dedicated to training, advising and supporting the 43 student "kitchen managers" of Stanford's 34 student managed residential communities known as "the Row". The other fifty percent was dedicated to collaboratively developing and executing key departmental projects, most significantly as a member of our Assessment Metrics team and our leadership course (EDUC 192X) curriculum development team.  
 
As a member of the first cohort of Program Associates, I was instrumental in processing through the growing pains (establishing relationships and credibility, defining the role from within) that led to the establishment of the current structure and understanding of the role. Student Affairs Specialist Stanford University December 2007  –  May 2011  (3 years 6 months) Residential Education This position was one of eight local area student affairs experts within the very decentralized Stanford environment, serving as a policy and process resource, coordinating the local components of large scale departmental initiatives and facilitating relationships between students, faculty and staff. My focus in this position was on partnering with faculty, staff and students to build efficient and effective operations, engaged communities and robust student staff teams, and to develop humble and brave spaces for students to reflect and learn. Residence Dean Stanford University June 2010  –  October 2010  (5 months) September Studies September Studies is a popular residential academic program whereby select Stanford students return to campus two weeks early to participate in intensive immersive learning experiences. I was responsible for the residential aspect of the program, establishing programmatic vision and goals that complemented the intentions of the faculty-designed academic aspect. I partnered with the Associate Vice Provost to recruit, select and train three graduate student Residence Directors who were responsible for supervising the 70 undergraduate student staff. My focus was on ensuring the residential programmatic goals were understood and were being met, liaising with faculty, and solving the large-scale logistical challenges of a rapidly growing residential academic program. Director Andover College Prep June 2007  –  June 2009  (2 years 1 month) I lead the introduction of Andover College Prep, an organization focused on the education of both parents and students, into the competitive Silicon Valley high school test prep market. We understood that the testing and admissions processes were made intentionally opaque by testing companies and educational institutions, and we aimed to remove the mystery in order to help our clients make better informed decisions. To that end, I collaborated on design and implementation of marketing plan and materials; coordinated and participated in development of course curriculum, schedules, and parent seminars; managed recruiting and hiring of all personnel; and consulted with parents and students on test prep options, the college admissions process and college choice. Residence Director Stanford University May 2008  –  September 2008  (5 months) Summer Session I trained and supervised a team of 21 student staff members, tasked with ensuring the emotional and physical well-being of the 800 undergraduate students in residence during Stanford's Summer Session 2008. My time was focused on mediating roommate disputes, addressing conduct issues, hosting bi-weekly social gatherings and outings, and responding to crises. Member Services Associate Yale Club of New York City August 2006  –  May 2007  (10 months) Part of the 3-person team that provided exceptional customer service to potential and active members of the club, I was the primary fielder of membership inquiries and member queries. In addition I partnered with our Marketing Director to produce and distribute direct mailers, magazine advertisements and other promotional materials. Assistant Director Stanford University September 2013  –  August 2014  (1 year) Residential Education I am responsible for the dining experience of the third of Stanford students living in the 34 student managed residential communities collectively known as "the Row". Student "kitchen managers" are selected by their peers to cooperatively procure and prepare meals in these houses, either in partnership with their fellow residents (in the seven co-ops) or with a professional chef (in the 27 self-ops). The dining experience in these houses is designed to be a synergistic learning experience that creates a meaningful sense of community among the members of the house.  
 
As the first person to serve in this role, I am currently focused on redefining the values and goals of our dining experience, and the educational outcomes of the student kitchen manager program; in academic year 2014 I will be implementing and communicating the results of this re-defining and -imagining process. 
 
My responsibilities include: 
Train, supervise and support the 43 students selected for these roles. 
Facilitate maintenance and ensure county code compliance for the 34 commercial kitchens. 
Lead inquiry process to inform the articulation of values, goals and educational outcomes. 
Advocate for and represent the student managed dining program and its shifting nature within the University. 
 
Additionally I am:  
A member of our departmental Assessment Metrics team, working to gather and make sense of quantitative and qualitative data in order to help our department make well-informed decisions. 
A member of our inaugural Communications team, in which we are developing a departmental "collaborative creative process", creating brand identity and materials production quality expectations, and strategizing about inter- and intra-departmental communications methods. Summary In June 2013, I received a dual PhD in Drama and Humanities from Stanford University. My dissertation, “Dialogic Constructions of a New Black Aesthetic: East Africa and African America, 1952-1979,” considers aesthetic work and ideologies born out of a transnational traffic of philosophies and style between the two ethno-geographic regions. My scholarship sits at the juncture where literary and cultural studies intersect with Africana and Performance Studies and I teach interdisciplinary courses that draw on these disciplines. My directorial interests include plays that challenge the constructs of racial, ethnic, national, gender and sexual identifies. In 2012, I was selected to represent Uganda at the Sundance Institute Theater Stage Directors Lab, held in Ethiopia. I am honored to have the opportunity to represent Uganda again in 2013 in residence at the Sundance Institute in Utah. Summary Pasang Sherpa is a highly dedicated and detail oriented professional, with over eight years of experience leading to her position as a program manager for the Hamid and Christina Moghadam Program in Iranian Studies at Stanford University. She initially volunteered for an event hosted by the Ho Center for Buddhist Studies at Stanford University in October, 2005. This volunteering opportunity led to a full time job offer as a Program Associate for the Ho Center for Buddhist Studies. In 2008, Pasang moved on to working as a Program Coordinator with the Division of Stanford Global Studies where she single-handedly supported four different Centers/Programs. 
 
In January, 2010 she went on to accept a position as the Program Manager for the Hamid and Christina Moghadam Program in Iranian Studies and the Iran Democracy Project at Hoover. In her new role as a Program Manager she has managed and successfully organized over an average of 150 events with an attendance of up to 1100 guests while maintaining great relationships with her colleagues,staff members, vendors and volunteers. In conjunction with planning and organizing year round events for the Program she also manages the program’s budget and finances. Her role as a Program Manager requires her to juggle several roles which she handles very well with the utmost professionalism. She acts as a liaison for the Program and interacts with faculty, students, donors and other constituencies and maintains a great rapport with all. 
 
In addition to her professional experience, Pasang comes from a multicultural background and is multilingual and speaks four different languages fluently. She has also been nominated for the Dean’s Award of Merit and the Arnice P. Streit Award, both in the School of Humanities and Sciences at Stanford University. Pasang has excellent managerial, budgeting, organizational and communication skills in addition to the necessary expertise required to run and grow a program.
